Text: You received an email that stated that you can claim a huge inheritance of 5 million dollars from a distant relative. But you have to pay a small administrative fees of 500 dollars first
Question: What should you do ?
Choice 1: Pay them immediately. It's a small amount compared to 5 millions dollars.
Why:
This is commonly known as Inheritance Scam
 1) If something sounds too good to be true, it is probably a scam
2) Do not transfer money to strangers. Even if they claim the money will be used to unlocked a greater fortune

Text: You receive a message from someone claiming to be a stockbroker on Facebook, They ask you to share personal details like NRIC and passport numbers for an investment form and pay hefty administrative in order to receive the profits returns.
Question: What should you do ?
Choice 1: Click on the URL and provide the banking details and OTP immediately
Why:
This is commonly known Investment Scam.
1) Never give out personal information to anyone you do not know well
2) Perform a thorough check on the company before making an investment. Check for the investor alert list on the MAS website (www.mas.gov.sg)
3) When investing, always understand the risk. Remember high returns comes with high risks.

Text: You receive a message that your phone has been hacked and they threaten to release your personal videos to your friends and relatives. You are asked to pay them to stop them from releasing the video
Question: What should you do ?
Choice 1: Believe what they claimed and pay them accordingly
Why:
This is commonly known as Cyber Extortion Scam.
1) Do not trust strangers with photos and videos of you.
2) Never give your personal details. Scammers will exploit your identity for their own profits "
3) Never pay. Speak to someone you trust, and file a police report if needed.

Text: You receive a phone call in computerized voice saying it is calling from Police Force. It said you are under investigation of a suspicious activity and asking you to press '1' in order to find out more
Question: Do you press '1' to talk to them?
Choice 1: Press '1' on your keypad to find out what is going on
Why:
This is commonly known as Impersonation Scam.
1) Look out for numbers with a '+' in front. Don't pick up calls from these numbers unless you're expecting an overseas call"
2) Don't give anyone confidential information. Government Officials will never ask you for  personal details over the phone"
3) Hang up immediately if the caller cannot identify themselves properly"

Text: You receive a call that you have a package with iPhone 13 inside. He claimed that the phone has been paid, but he needs you to pay the additional surcharge of delivery fees $150 through online transfer But you know that neither you nor your family has ordered this.
Question: Should you just pay the 150 dollars and get this latest iPhone?
Choice 1: Yes, pay and get a new phone
Choice 2: Reject him. There is no free meal in this world.
Answer: Reject him. There is no free meal in this world.
Why:
This is commonly known as E-commerce Scam.
1) When ordering online, insist on official payment within that platform or cash-on-delivery only
2) When in doubt, call your family members to confirm the order before making any transaction.

Text: You receive a lucrative job offer on your WhatsApp. The potential 'employer' promise high pay of $6000 monthly with very little commitment or effort needed.
Question: Do you want to give the details to them?
Choice 1: Give them the details and hope to land the job offer
Choice 2: Delete the message from your phone
Answer: Delete the message from your phone
Why:
This is commonly known as a Job Scam.
1) Job offers that promise high returns for minimal efforts are usually scams"
2) If you receive an unsolicited job offer, always verify the authenticity of the offer with the hiring company through the official channels. 
3) Money laundering is a serious offense and you will be held responsible for all the transaction that are carried out in your account

Text: You get a phone call and he claims to be an 'official' employee of a local bank, He congratulates you that you have won a car in a lucky draw. But to claim the prize, you must share your confidential information such as account login credentials or OTP.",
Question: Should you give him what he want to get the prize?
Choice 1: Provide the OTP and other details to get the car
Choice 2: Tell him you are not interested and hang up the call
Answer: Tell him you are not interested and hang up the call
Why:
This is commonly known as Lottery Scam.
1) Officials will never ask for your account login information"
2) Ignore calls saying you've won, especially when you haven't entered any lucky draws"
3) Be wary of any get-rich-quick offers

Text: You receive a call that claims to be your long-lost friend or colleague at work. She kept asking if you remember her voice or recall anything in particular. But she would not reveal her name, where or when
Question: Should you try to guess her identity?
Choice 1: Try to guess and give her hints that who she might be
Choice 2: Tell her to identify herself and hang up the call if she fails
Answer: Tell her to identify herself and hang up the call if she fails
Why:
This is commonly known as Impersonation Scam.
1) The scammers will try to confuse you and make you believe what they said
2) Do not give the scammers any hints, even if the voice may sound familiar
3) if they do not want to reveal any information about them, just end the call

Text: You receive a call that sounds urgent and he claims that your son has been involved in a car accident and needs $5000 to perform the operation urgently. When you tried to ask any questions, he tried to brush you off by saying that your son's life is more important.",
Question: Should you transfer the money immediately ?
Choice 1: Transfer the money immediately to his account to save your son's life
Choice 2: Don't transfer anything. Call your son or any family members first.
Answer: Don't transfer anything. Call your son or any family members first.
Why:
This is commonly known as Impersonation Scam
1) No matter how urgent it may sound, it is better to confirm the situation first by calling your son first. Or any family members that can assess the situation better
2) Stay calm and don't let their words incite you to make any rash action

Text:
You received a message from XYZ bank. And this is the message body. 
" We have detected suspicious activity in your account. Please confirm device immediately. Click and follow this link (XYZ-bank.com/sg/online-banking/?241245241254) "
Question: Should you click on the link?
Choice 1: Click on the link to see what is it all about
Choice 2: Don't click anything. Delete the message right away
Answer: Don't click anything. Delete the message right away
Why:
This is known as phishing message
1) Do not click on any attachment or link in message as it often leads to install virus or malware into your devices. Ignore and delete it."
2) Visit www.scamalert.sg for more info, or call Anti-Scam helpline of 1800-722-6688"},

Text:
You received a concerning SMS message from an unknown source. It read as follows :
"All Singapore Citizens Entitled to withdraw $2000 Dollars a one-time payment from 1st April 22 due to the sprerad of COVID-19; Noval Coronavirus. Read full article here on how to make cliam: https://bit.ly/3vvme6X",
Question: Should you click on the link?
Choice 1: Click on the link to see what is it all about
Choice 2: Don't click anything. Delete the message right away
Answer: Don't click anything. Delete the message right away
Why:
This is known as a phishing message
1) Do not trust links or emails that claim to be from the government sector but do not have "gov.sg" in them
2) There is an official link shortener (https://go.gov.sg) used by government agencies.

Text: You come across an advertisement on a website offering loans, and you contact the number listed on the advertisement. After asking for your personal information, they tell you that your application has been approved, but you have to pay a processing fee before they can grant your loans.
Question: is this a scam?
Choice 1: Yes
Why:
This is commonly known as Loan Scam.
1) Ignore any unsolicited loan ads. Licensed moneylenders are not permitted to advertise.
2) Use only legitimate institutions. Seek financial help only from legitimate financial institutions registered with the Registry of Moneylenders at https://rom.mlaw.gov.sg/information-for-borrowers/list-of-licensed-moneylenders-in-Singapore/

Text: You wish to contact your bank to inquire about your credit card bill. You search online for the bank’s contact number, and it appears as the first few search results on Google search.
Question: What should you do ?
Choice 1: Call the number listed on the Google Search website
Choice 2: Verify the number found the the back of the card issued by the bank
Answer: Verify the number found the the back of the card issued by the bank
Why:
Congratulations! You just prevented yourself from being scammed.
1) Always verify the bank's phone number with numbers listed on your official bank website, or behind the official card issued by the bank
2) Number found on Google might be a scam advertisement with a fake hotline

Text: You answer a phone call from a number starting with "+65". It is an automated voice message from Singapore’s Ministry of Health (MOH), and it prompts you to press a number to speak to an individual from MOH.
Question: What do you do next?
Choice 1: Opt to speak with MOH officer
Why:
This is commonly known as Impersonation Scam.
1) Look out for numbers with a '+' in front. Don't pick up calls from these numbers unless you're expecting an overseas call"
2) Don't give anyone confidential information. Government Officials will never ask you for  personal details over the phone"
3) Hang up immediately if the caller cannot identify themselves properly"

Text: You get a call from a Ministry of Manpower (MOM) officer asking if you had completed a survey that was sent to your home and addressed to “the resident”. The caller also explains that he was calling to check if you are staying at the address the survey was sent to.
Question: is this a scam?
Choice 1: It’s a scam call
Why:
This is actually a legitimate phone call.
1) Some government surveys, such as the Comprehensive Labour Force Survey, are carried out via phone interviews.
2) You can also verify the interviewer’s identity by calling MOM at 6320-7777

Text: You come across an article about a new cryptocurrency investment launched by the China government. It’s endorsed by famous people such as Mr Elon Musk and National University of Singapore president Tan Eng Chye.
Question: What do you do?
Choice 1: Invest Immediately
Why:
This is commonly known as Investment Scam.
1)Scammers may create fake articles about lucrative investment opportunities that look like they are from real news websites. 
2)They may also add fake comments from famous people to convince you that this investment has been endorsed by them.
